newsitem.title: HONG KONG: HK activists set off for disputed isles - again.
newsitem.headline: HK activists set off for disputed isles - again.

text.p: A group of 20 Hong Kong activists set off by ship on a protest voyage to disputed islands in the East China Sea on Friday after rough seas and seasickness forced them back to port on Thursday night.

The group had sailed off originally in high spirits, chanting they would "fight to the death", but the weather forced them to stop and seek refuge in a bay in Hong Kong's New Territories, where they spent the night.

The members of the Action Committee for Defending the Diaoyu Islands plan to land on the small, uninhabited islands -- known as the Diaoyus in China and Senkakus in Japan -- as a show of support for China's claims of sovereignty.
Taiwan and Japan also claim the islands.
The activists plan first to go to Taiwan's southern Kaohsiung port where they will be joined by a group of Taiwanese supporters. The protesters will then sail to the isles and camp there overnight.
A spokeswoman for the Hong Kong group said the timing of their arrival at the islands depended on weather conditions.
Earlier in May, a Japanese rightist group led by legislator Shingo Nishimura landed on the islands and raised a Japanese flag, triggering the latest round of protests.

Last year, there were angry anti-Japanese protests in Taiwan, China, Hong Kong and a number of Chinese communities around the world after another ultra-rightwing Japanese group erected a makeshift lighthouse on one of the islands.
